Computer Methods and Programs in Biomedicine (2005) 77, 129-139
Robust tests for the multivariate Behrens-Fisher
problem
Lisa M. Lix a, * , H.J. Keselman b , Aynslie M. Hinds a
a Department of Community Health Sciences, Faculty of Medicine, University of Manitoba, 408-727
McDermot Avenue, Winnipeg, Man., Canada R3E 3P5
b Department of Psychology, University of Manitoba, Winnipeg, Man., Canada R3T 2N2
Received 2 December 2003 ; received in revised form 9 July 2004; accepted 9 September 2004
KEYWORDS
Multivariate;
Mean equality;
Two-group design;
Robust estimation;
Covariance
heterogeneity
Summary Hotelling's T 2 procedure is used to test the equality of means in two-
group multivariate designs when covariances are homogeneous. A number of alter-
natives to T 2 , which are robust to covariance heterogeneity, have been proposed in
the literature. However, all are sensitive to departures from multivariate normal-
ity. We demonstrate how to obtain multivariate tests that are robust to covariance
heterogeneity and non-normality with estimators of location and scale based on
trimming and Winsorizing. The performance of six alternatives to T 2 was examined
via Monte Carlo methods when characteristics of the research design, degree of co-
variance heterogeneity, and degree of non-normality were manipulated. We have
recently developed a program written in the SAS/IML language that can be used to
implement these robust multivariate tests. Recommendations are provided on the
specific data-analytic conditions under which these tests should be adopted.

1. Introduction
Medical researchers are frequently interested in
testing hypotheses about the efficacy of treatments
for two independent groups of subjects. Treatment
effectiveness is often assessed using multiple out-
come variables [1-3], such as physiological re-
sponses and subjective assessments of quality of
life [4].

Student's t-statistic is the conventional approach
for testing the equality of population means for
two independent groups on a single outcome vari-
able when population variances are equal and the
data are normally distributed. It is well known that
Student's t is sensitive to departures from the as-
sumption of variance homogeneity and that Welch's
statistic [5] should be favored when variances are
unequal. However, because Welch's statistic is sen-
sitive to departures from a normal distribution,
Reed [6] considered a modification when normality
can not be assumed. A robust test can be obtained
by trimming/Winsorizing the most extreme obser-
vations from the tails of a distribution, a solution

recommended by Yuen and Dixon [7] and Yuen [8],
prior to computing Welch's statistic.
The multivariate extension of Student's t-
procedure, Hotelling's T 2 [9], tests the equality of
means on multiple outcome variables. The T 2 test
rests on the assumptions of equality of the group
covariances and a joint normal distribution for the
outcomes. T 2 is biased when covariances are het-
erogeneous [10-12], particularly when the design is
unbalanced, that is, when group sizes are unequal.
A number of alternatives, which are robust (i.e.,
insensitive) to covariance heterogeneity, have been
proposed in the literature [13-19]. Like T 2 , all of
these procedures rely on the assumption of multi-
variate normality.
When the data are obtained from non-normal
distributions, multivariate procedures for testing
mean equality will produce biased results, partic-
ularly when the design is unbalanced [10,20-23].
Wilcox [23] demonstrated that a two-group multi-
variate procedure, which is robust to the effects of
both covariance heterogeneity and non-normality
may be obtained by substituting robust estimators
for the usual (i.e., least-squares) means and covari-
ances in procedures, which are robust to covariance
heterogeneity. More specifically, Wilcox derived ro-
bust analogues of the Johansen [24] and Kim [16]
procedures by replacing least-squares estimators
with estimators based on trimming/Winsorization.
He observed that both of these robust procedures
controlled the rate of Type I errors to the nominal
level of significance, α, when covariances were het-
erogeneous and the data were non-normal. More-
over, these procedures were more powerful than
those based on least-squares estimators when the
data were obtained from skewed or heavy-tailed
distributions.
Fouladi and Yockey [25] examined six alterna-
tives to Hotelling's T 2 [9] under conditions of co-
variance heterogeneity, including James' first and
second-order [14], Johansen [24], Kim [16], Nel and
van der Merwe [17], and Yao [19] procedures. None
of the procedures demonstrated superior perfor-
mance across all data-analytic conditions; each was
influenced by such factors as total sample size, the
ratio of the group sizes, the correlation between
outcome variables, and the ratio of the group sizes
to the number of outcome variables. While Fouladi
and Yockey [25] observed that the presence of non-
normal data did not have an adverse effect on the
Type I error control of the alternate procedures,
they considered only very modest departures from
normality. Previous research has demonstrated the
sensitivity of multivariate procedures to departures
from normality, particularly when the distributions
are skewed [26].
This paper extends previous research by Reed
[6] on robust tests for two-group univariate de-
signs to the multivariate context. The Type I error
performance of several alternatives to Hotelling's
T 2 [9] test under departures from the assumptions
of covariance homogeneity and multivariate nor-
mality are compared. The investigated procedures
include those considered by Fouladi and Yockey
[25] in addition to a multivariate extension of
the Brown-Forsythe [27] procedure [28,29]. These
tests are investigated when least-squares estima-
tors are employed and when least-squares esti-
mators are replaced with robust estimators based
on trimming/Winsorization. A computer program to
implement these robust strategies is described and
a numeric example is presented.

4. Simulation methods
A Monte Carlo study was used to evaluate the Type
I error performance of Hotelling's T 2 [9] and the six
alternatives for the two-group multivariate prob-
lem. Eight factors were manipulated in the study.
These were: (a) number of outcome variables, (b)
degree of correlation between outcome variables,
(c) total sample size, (d) degree of group size bal-
ance/imbalance, (e) equality/inequality of group
covariance matrices, (f) degree of inequality of
group covariance matrices, (g) nature of the pair-
ing of group sizes and group covariance matrices,
and (h) population distribution. The choice of fac-
tor levels was based on previous research.
The value of p, the number of outcome vari-
ables, was set at two, four, and eight. The degree
of correlation among the outcome variables, was
set at ρ = 0.1, 0.5, and 0.8. Without loss of general-
ity, the correlation was introduced for the second-
group only, while the intercorrelation among the
outcome variables for the first group was set at
ρ = 0 [25].

conditions were examined for each value of p such
that the total number of observations ranged from
18 to 192. For p = 2, the ratio of N/p was set at 9,

The procedures were investigated when the
group covariance matrices were equal and unequal.
In the latter case, both moderate and large de-
grees of covariance inequality were examined. In
the moderate inequality case, the matrices were in
the ratio of 1:5. In the large covariance inequality
case, the matrices were in a ratio of 1:9.
Both positive and negative pairings of group sizes
and covariance matrices were investigated. A pos-
itive pairing refers to the case in which the largest
n j is associated with the covariance matrix contain-
ing the largest element values; a negative pairing
refers to the case in which the largest n j is associ-
ated with the covariance matrix with the smallest
element values.
Type I error rates were obtained when the data
were both multivariate normal and non-normal in
form. For the former, pseudorandom observation
vectors Y ij from a multivariate normal distribution
with mean vector ␤ j and covariance matrix j were
obtained using the SAS generator RANNOR [32]. To
obtain each Y ij , a row vector of p deviates in which
each element has a standard normal distribution
(i.e., Z ij ), was transformed to a vector of multi-
variate observations via a triangular (Cholesky) de-
composition
Y ij = ␤ j + LZ T

where L is a upper triangular matrix of dimension p
satisfying the equality L T L = j . Three non-normal
distributions were investigated: heavy-tailed, mod-
erately skewed, and highly skewed. The heavy-
tailed distribution had skewness (γ 1 ) and kurto-
sis (γ 2 ) values equivalent to those of a double-
exponential distribution (i.e., γ 1 = 0; γ 2 = 3). The
moderately skewed distribution had the same skew-
ness and kurtosis values as an exponential distribu-
tion (i.e., γ 1 = 2; γ 2 = 6). The highly skewed distribu-
tion had γ 1 = 6.18 and γ 2 = 110.93, which are equiv-
alent to the shape parameters of a lognormal distri-
bution. The non-normal data were generated by the
method developed by Fleishman [33] and extended
to the multivariate situation by Vale and Maurelli
[34].
The simulation program was written in the
SAS/Interactive Matrix Language (IML) pro-
gramming language [35]. For each of the
3 × 3 × 3 × 4 = 108 combinations of p, ρ, N, and
population distribution, we examined both equal
and unequal covariance matrices for balanced and
unbalanced designs. Five thousand replications
of each condition were performed using a 0.05
significance level. For each replication, the seven
statistics were computed using least-squares and
robust estimators.
Descriptive analyses of empirical Type I error
rates and of the percentage of bias in the error
rates, B = 100(α − α)/α, were conducted. Inferen-
tial analyses involved a between-subjects factorial
analysis of variance (ANOVA), to assess the signif-
icance of each of the simulation variables in ex-
plaining variation in empirical error rates. Sepa-
rate ANOVA models were defined for balanced and
unbalanced designs. For the former, a base model
was defined that included main effect predictors
only: number of outcome variables (VAR), corre-
lation between outcome variables (CORR), total
sample size (NTOT), covariance structure (homo-
geneous, heterogeneous: COV), and population dis-
tribution (POPTYPE). For the latter, two different
base models, each containing only main effect pre-
dictors, were defined. The first base model con-
tained VAR, CORR, NTOT, POPTYPE, as well as the
pairing of group sizes and covariance matrices (pos-
itive, negative: PAIR), and the degree of covari-
ance inequality (RATIO). The second included all of
these predictors except NTOT, which was replaced
by n j , the coefficient of variation of group size
inequality (CV). Not all values of CV were repre-

sented at each value of N, therefore it was impos-
sible to include both variables in the base model.
Full models, which were included main effect pre-
dictors as well as selected two-way interactions,
were also specified for both balanced and unbal-
anced designs; these are described in more detail
in Section 5.
An empirical criterion of robustness defined by
Bradley [36] was also used to assess performance of
the test procedures. According to Bradley's liberal
criterion, a procedure is robust if its empirical error
rate falls within the interval from 0.025 to 0.075
for α = 0.05. A procedure was considered liberal if
its empirical Type I error rate was greater than the
upper bound of this criterion, while a procedure
was considered conservative if its error rate was
below the lower bound of this criterion.
5. Results
5.1. ANOVA results for balanced designs
Table 2 contains the ANOVA results for balanced and
unbalanced designs for least-squares and trimmed
estimators. The results are presented for the base
model, as well as for a full model, which includes
selected two-way interactions designed to investi-
gate the effect of non-normality.
For balanced designs, the proportion of varia-
tion (R 2 ) explained by the set of main effect pre-
dictors in the base model for the procedures based
on least-squares estimators ranged from 0.40 for BF
to 0.81 for J. The predictors were statistically sig-
nificant in all of the models, with the exception of
CORR, which was only significant in the model for
the J procedure, NTOT, which was not significant
in the models for the H, BF, N, and Y procedures,
and VAR, which was not significant in the model for
the BF procedure. The proportion of variation ex-
plained by the base model predictors was higher
for robust estimators than for least-squares estima-
tors for all test procedures. The explained variation
ranged from 0.56 for the NV test to 0.96 for J. For
robust estimators, all of the predictors in the base
model were significant with the exception of CORR,
which was a non-significant predictor for the H and
J2 procedures.

highly skewed distributions, mean error rates fre-
quently exceeded the upper bound of Bradley's
criterion when least-squares estimators were
adopted but not when trimmed estimators were
adopted.
5.2. ANOVA results for unbalanced designs
For unbalanced designs, the two base models,
which contained the CV and NTOT predictors, re-
spectively, explained a similar proportion of the
variation in the data for all but the J procedure,
for which CV was a better predictor of Type I error
rates than NTOT. Hence, we selected the former
base model for our model comparisons. The pro-
portion of variation explained by the predictors in
the base model ranged from 0.42 for K to 0.75 for
H for least-squares estimators (Table 2). For the H
procedure, all predictors were significant with the
exception of CORR and POPTYPE. For the J2, J, NV,
and Y procedures, CORR was a non-significant pre-
dictor. CV was a non-significant predictor for the BF,
J2, and K procedures. RATIO was not significant for
the Y procedure, and VAR was not significant for the
BF procedure.
When trimmed estimators were adopted, the
proportion of variation explained by predictors in
the base model ranged from 0.52 for the K proce-
dure to 0.76 for the H procedure. CORR was a non-
significant predictor for the J2 and J procedures,
while RATIO was non-significant for the Y proce-
dure. VAR was non-significant only for the H pro-
cedure, as was POPTYPE. The PAIR variable was not
significant for the J2 procedure.
For the full model, which included main ef-
fect predictors and both POPTYPE × CV and POP-
TYPE × PAIR, the proportion of explained variation
increased between 0.01 and 0.34 for least-squares
estimators and between 0.01 and 0.16 for trimmed
estimators. The interaction terms were significant
in all of the full models for least-squares estima-
tors, with the exception of the model for the H
procedure, where neither were significant. In the
full models for procedures based on trimmed esti-
mators, POPTYPE × CV was not significant for the
H and Y procedures, while POPTYPE × PAIR was not
significant for the H procedure.
Descriptive analyses (Table 3) revealed that for
least-squares estimators, Type I error rates were
substantially different for positive and negative
pairings of group sizes and covariance matrices
when the data were obtained from multivariate
normal and non-normal distributions. This variation
was less obvious when trimmed estimators were
adopted. Table 3 contains the mean percentages
of Type I error for all of the investigated proce-
dures for positive and negative pairings of group
sizes and covariance matrices. For positive pairings,
mean error rates were contained within the bounds
of Bradley's [36] liberal criterion for both least-
squares and trimmed estimators for all but the H
and J procedures. Error rates for the former were
conservative, while those for the latter were lib-
eral; the degree of liberalness was greater for non-
normal distributions when least-squares estimators
were adopted than when robust estimators were
adopted. In particular, the J procedure with least-
squares estimators tended to be quite liberal when
the ratio of n min /p was 3 or less and/or when n j
was large. For example, the mean Type I error rate
for n min /p = 4.5 when n j = 1.22 was 6.35 for nor-
mally distributed data when least-squares estima-
tors were adopted and was 5.88 when robust esti-
mators were adopted. However, when n min /p = 4.5
when n j = 6.12, the mean error rates were 9.74
and 6.44 for least-squares and trimmed estimators,
respectively.
For negative pairings, liberal values were ob-
served for the H procedure across all of the inves-
tigated population distributions. For the remaining
six procedures, liberal results were obtained for the
moderately and highly skewed distributions when
least-squares estimators were adopted for all but
the K procedure in the latter distribution. When
trimmed estimators were adopted, the NV and Y
procedures produced liberal values for both the
moderately and highly skewed distributions, while
the BF procedure was conservative for the normal
distribution, and the K procedure was conservative
for the heavy-tailed distribution.

5.3. Percentages of bias
We investigated the percentages of bias for each
of the alternatives to Hotelling's T 2 [9] procedure
when covariances were heterogeneous and the de-
sign was either balanced or unbalanced (Table 4).
When the design was balanced, procedures based
on least-squares estimators were only slightly bi-
ased (15.47-28.44%) in either a positive or nega-
tive direction when the data were obtained from
a normal distribution. The degree of variation in
bias increased only slightly when the data were ob-
tained from a heavy-tailed distribution (−23.18% to
20.26%); the greatest degree of positive bias was for
the J procedure and the greatest degree of negative
bias was for the K procedure. For the moderately
skewed distribution, the procedures based on least-
squares estimators exhibited positive bias ranging
from 30.86% (K) to 98.44% (J). When the data were
highly skewed the percent of positive bias ranged
from 5.90% (K) to 70.90% (J). When the design was
balanced and trimmed estimators were adopted,
the bias tended to be slightly negative for the
normal distribution (−30.07% to 17.24%) and the
heavy-tailed distribution (−36.09% to 6.11%). For
both of the skewed distributions, the procedures
based on trimmed estimators exhibited a smaller
degree of positive bias than when least-squares es-
timators were adopted. In fact, the BF, J2, and K
exhibited a slight negative bias.
When group sizes and covariance matrices were
positively paired, the procedures based on least-
squares estimators were only slightly biased regard-
less of the shape of the population distribution.
The exception was for the J procedure, which was
always highly positively biased. For trimmed esti-
mators, the procedures almost always exhibited a
small degree of negative bias, with the exception

6. Conclusions
Hotelling's T 2 [9] is sensitive to departures from co-
variance heterogeneity and multivariate normality
for two-group designs. A number of alternatives to
T 2 have been proposed in the literature. When the
data are normally distributed and least-squares es-
timators are adopted, no one procedure is supe-
rior across all data-analytic situations. When the
data are non-normal and least-squares estimators
are adopted, error rates can deviate substantially
from α, particularly when the distribution is skewed
and the group with the smallest sample size exhibits
the largest degree of covariance heterogeneity.
Procedures that are insensitive to departures
from covariance heterogeneity and non-normality
can be obtained when trimmed estimators are sub-
stituted for least-squares estimators in procedures
that are robust to covariance heterogeneity. Again,

no single procedure will perform well in all data-
analytic situations. As the results demonstrate, the
Brown and Forsythe [27], James second-order [14],
and Kim [16] procedures are frequently conserva-
tive. The Johansen procedure [24] is sensitive to
the relationship between group sizes and the di-
mensionality of the data, and will produce liberal
values when the ratio of the smallest group size to
the number of outcome variables is small, or when
the degree of group size imbalance is large. The
Nel and van der Merwe [17]and Yao [19] procedures
were more liberal than other procedures when the
group with the smallest sample size exhibited the
largest degree of covariance heterogeneity.
Based on these findings, we recommend that re-
searchers adopt procedures based on trimmed esti-
mators if the assumption of multivariate normality
is untenable. If the degree of group size imbalance
is large, and the ratio of the smallest group size
to the number of outcome variables is small, the
Johansen procedure[24] should be avoided. If the
degree of covariance heterogeneity is large, then
Kim's procedure [16] should be considered, since
it was the only procedure in unbalanced designs,
which was insensitive to the degree of covariance
heterogeneity in the data. Overall, the Kim and
James second-order procedures based on robust es-
timators were less sensitive to the factors examined
in this study than the other four alternative proce-
dures.
7. Software and numeric example
We recently developed a computer program writ-
ten in version 8 of SAS' Interactive Matrix Language
that can be used to implement these robust al-
ternatives with trimmed estimators [37]. This pro-
gram, along with instructions on its use, is avail-
able for downloading from the first author's web-
site, http://home.cc.umanitoba.ca/∼lixlm. This
program requires that the data matrix of multi-
variate observations, group sizes, and proportion
of trimming be specified. For the current example,
we examined the procedures using 20% symmetric
trimming because this amount of trimming has been
often recommended in the literature. However, the
program user may select any amount of symmet-
ric trimming desired. The program will output sum-
mary descriptive information, including the multi-
variate group means and covariance matrices. The
test statistics, degrees of freedom, and p-values or
critical values for each of the procedures, as de-
fined in Sections 2 and 3, are produced.
We demonstrate the application of the program
using a data set obtained from Selvin [38] on ma-
ternal weights for 70 primiparous and 23 multi-
parous women (p. 223). Six measures of prepreg-
nancy, pregnancy, and postpartum weights, gains,
and losses were analyzed by Selvin using Hotelling's
T 2 [9]. We applied the robust alternatives to these
data. To illustrate the effect that extreme observa-
tions can have on the statistical tests when least-
squares estimators are adopted, we manipulated
the data so that a constant was added to the first
six observations for the last dependent variable for
the primiparous women. This modified data set is
available from the authors on request.
The results generated by the SAS/IML program
are presented in Table 5. Note that with least-
squares estimators all procedures result in rejec-
tion of the null hypothesis of equality of multivari-
ate means for the two groups of women, while with
trimmed estimators the null hypothesis is retained.
In this example, all of the tests based on robust es-
timators lead to the same decision regarding the
null hypothesis. However, as the simulation results
reported in this paper indicate, this will not neces-
sarily be the case for all data sets.
